concepts.name: Prisoner's Dilemma
concepts.shortDefinition: Individual rational behavior can lead to a collectively bad outcome
concepts.elaboration: In the classic example, if A and B both don't confess, they get off scot-free. If they both confess, they each get 5 years in prison. If one confesses and the other does not, the confessor gets released with a reward, and the non-confessor gets 10 years in prison. The individually rational outcome leads to both confessing.

concepts.name: First Iron Law
concepts.shortDefinition: Sometimes it's this way, and sometimes it's that way
concepts.elaboration: Correlations show tendencies, not certainties. Individual exceptions don't disprove patterns, but patterns don't predict individual cases with certainty.

concepts.name: Dunbar's Number
concepts.shortDefinition: Approximately 150 people - the cognitive limit for stable social relationships
concepts.elaboration: Organizations above this size require formal structure rather than informal coordination.

concepts.name: binary data
concepts.shortDefinition: data from situations that can be either/or
concepts.elaboration: Data from situations that can be either/or, such as Democrat or Republican

concepts.name: categorical data
concepts.shortDefinition: data with multiple discrete categories
concepts.elaboration: Data that from situations that can have multiple discrete categories, such as Democrat, Republican, or Green Party.

concepts.name: scalar data
concepts.shortDefinition: data that can have more or less
concepts.elaboration: Data that come from situations where there can be more or less, such as the number of votes a candidate received, or the percentage of votes a candidate received

concepts.name: correlation
concepts.shortDefinition: measure of how two variables move together
concepts.elaboration: A measure of the extent to which two scalar data variables move together. Height and weight are positively correlated. Body fat and print speed are negatively correlated.

concepts.name: spurious correlation
concepts.shortDefinition: correlation that doesn't hold up in larger samples
concepts.elaboration: Correlation that appears in a small sample and does not hold up in a larger population

concepts.name: reverse causation
concepts.shortDefinition: when Y actually causes X instead of X causing Y
concepts.elaboration: When someone asserts that X causes Y, when it is possible or even likely that Y causes X

concepts.name: third-factor causation
concepts.shortDefinition: when a third factor causes both X and Y
concepts.elaboration: Also called Confounding Variable. When X and Y are correlated because a third factor, Z, is causing both

concepts.name: p-hacking
concepts.shortDefinition: tweaking analysis to get publishable results
concepts.elaboration: In layman's term p-hacking is when a researcher keeps tweaking the analysis to get a result that it likely to be worthy of publication

concepts.name: social desirability bias
concepts.shortDefinition: bias toward academically popular conclusions
concepts.elaboration: Economist Bryan Caplan's claim that it is easier to get a paper published if its results support opinions about the topic that are popular with academics.

concepts.name: replication crisis
concepts.shortDefinition: many studies fail to replicate when repeated
concepts.elaboration: Replication means getting similar results with a similar study done by another researcher. The crisis is that many studies, in psychology, epidemiology, and other fields, including studies heavily cited, have failed to replicate

concepts.name: Hill criteria
concepts.shortDefinition: Bradford Hill's criteria for establishing causality
concepts.elaboration: Bradford Hill's criteria for strengthening the case for causality in relationship found in epidemiology. Includes consistency of findings (not just one study), plausible causal mechanism, and larger values of the causal variable leading to larger effects in the result variable.

concepts.name: measurement error
concepts.shortDefinition: inaccurate measurement reduces correlation
concepts.elaboration: Measurement error reduces correlation. Conversely, if there is strong correlation, we can infer that measurement error is not a major issue

concepts.name: Warriors and Worriers
concepts.shortDefinition: Benenson's theory of gender behavioral differences
concepts.elaboration: Joyce Benenson's theories of different behavioral propensities of men and women, why these propensities evolved, and anthropological evidence for this

concepts.name: 90 percent chimp, 10 percent bee
concepts.shortDefinition: humans balance competition and cooperation
concepts.elaboration: Bees cooperate a lot and do not compete, chimps compete a lot and cooperate very little. Psychologist Jonathan Haidt says that humans excel at both, but with a bias toward competition.

concepts.name: The Blank Slate
concepts.shortDefinition: the view that behavior is entirely cultural
concepts.elaboration: Steven Pinker defends evolutionary psychology against the view that human behavior is entirely culturally determined. He says that his opponents think of the human brain as a blank slate, meaning that it has no tendencies imprinted by evolution.

concepts.name: Folk Theory of Mind
concepts.shortDefinition: how people judge if something has a mind
concepts.elaboration: Arnold Kling describes the findings of Daniel Wegner and Kurt Gray that people tend to think of an entity as having a mind if it has agency (the ability to make choices) and feelings (the ability to experience pain and other feelings).

concepts.name: Moral Dyad
concepts.shortDefinition: moral judgments divide actors into agents or patients
concepts.elaboration: From Daniel Wegner and Kurt Gray the observation that our moral judgments tend to divide actors into either having agency (they call this the robot) or having feelings (they call this the baby).

concepts.name: Secret of Our Success
concepts.shortDefinition: human advantage comes from collective intelligence
concepts.elaboration: In the book The Secret our Success anthropologist Joseph Henrich points out that the advantage that humans have over other species is our collective brains rather than our individual brains.

concepts.name: learning by copying
concepts.shortDefinition: copying others is usually better than innovating
concepts.elaboration: When a human encounters a novel problem, the best solution is usually to copy another human who has dealt with a similar problem. Choosing instead to innovate is risky, and it tends to pay off only in rapidly-changing environments.

concepts.name: cultural evolution
concepts.shortDefinition: humans accumulate shared knowledge across generations
concepts.elaboration: Humans are unique in that we accumulate shared knowledge. This means that cultural evolution is more rapid than biological evolution, especially in recent centuries. Other species rely on biological evolution, which is much slower.

concepts.name: The three e's
concepts.shortDefinition: experimentation, evaluation, and evolution
concepts.elaboration: Experimentation means trying new ideas. Evaluation means examining the results. Evolution means keeping ideas that work and discarding ideas that do not work or that used to work but are now obsolete.

concepts.name: beliefs are social
concepts.shortDefinition: we decide what to believe by deciding who to believe
concepts.elaboration: Arnold Kling has an aphorism that we decide what to believe by deciding who to believe. This raises the question of how we decide who to believe.

concepts.name: prestige hierarchy
concepts.shortDefinition: hierarchy based on admiration
concepts.elaboration: A hierarchy in which the people at the top are admired by people lower down

concepts.name: dominance hierarchy
concepts.shortDefinition: hierarchy based on fear
concepts.elaboration: A hierarchy in which the people at the top are feared by people lower down

concepts.name: Extraversion
concepts.shortDefinition: Big Five trait - outgoing and energetic
concepts.elaboration: Part of the Big Five personality model. The more extraverted you are, the more you are outgoing and show positive energy

concepts.name: Openness
concepts.shortDefinition: Big Five trait - receptive to new experiences
concepts.elaboration: Part of the Big Five personality model. The higher your openness, the more receptive you are to new ideas and experiences.

concepts.name: Conscientiousness
concepts.shortDefinition: Big Five trait - reliable and organized
concepts.elaboration: Part of the Big Five personality model. The higher your level of conscientiousness, the more you can be relied on to keep commitments. Higher conscientiousness has been shown to be predictive of better life outcomes.

concepts.name: Agreeableness
concepts.shortDefinition: Big Five trait - cooperative and trusting
concepts.elaboration: Part of the Big Five personality model. The higher your level of agreeableness, the more you tend to go along with the opinions and preferences of people around you.

concepts.name: Emotional instability
concepts.shortDefinition: Big Five trait - prone to negative emotions
concepts.elaboration: Part of the Big Five personality model. The higher your level of emotional instability, the more strongly you experience sadness or anger when you encounter problems. Was formerly called neuroticism.

concepts.name: HEXACO
concepts.shortDefinition: six-factor personality model including honesty
concepts.elaboration: A six-factor model of personality. The main difference with the Big Five model is the inclusion of the H component, which stands for honesty/humility.

concepts.name: honesty/humility
concepts.shortDefinition: HEXACO trait - fair and sincere behavior
concepts.elaboration: The higher your level of honesty/humility, the more you try to be fair, genuine, and sincere in your dealings with others.

concepts.name: Dark Triad
concepts.shortDefinition: narcissism, psychopathy, and Machiavellianism
concepts.elaboration: A combination of narcissism, psychopathy, and Machiavellianism. The higher you are in Dark Triad traits, the more willing you are to manipulate others. If you are skilled, you may succeed at exploiting others for money, power, or sex. But many people with Dark Triad traits have bad life outcomes.

concepts.name: informal personality psychology
concepts.shortDefinition: everyday theories about predicting behavior
concepts.elaboration: These are ideas the any person uses to try to predict, explain, and influence the behavior of other people.

concepts.name: formal personality psychology
concepts.shortDefinition: statistical models for predicting behavior
concepts.elaboration: Statistical models developed by psychologists to try to predict, explain, and influence the behavior of other people.

concepts.name: naive realism
concepts.shortDefinition: believing your perspective is objectively true
concepts.elaboration: The belief that your perspective on reality is true. It is naive because all of us have biases and shortcomings

concepts.name: myside bias
concepts.shortDefinition: trusting your tribe, distrusting others
concepts.elaboration: A tendency to be to place too much trust in the beliefs of people in your social tribe and to be too skeptical of the beliefs of people in a different social tribe

concepts.name: asymmetric insight
concepts.shortDefinition: thinking you understand others' motives better than they do
concepts.elaboration: The belief that you understand other people's motives better than they understand their own motives. In particular, when someone disagrees with you, instead of examining the substance of their argument you dismiss them as evil.

concepts.name: steel-manning
concepts.shortDefinition: examining the strongest opposing arguments
concepts.elaboration: Examining the strongest possible arguments that could be made by someone on the other side.

concepts.name: Constitution of Knowledge
concepts.shortDefinition: Rauch's term for truth-seeking institutions
concepts.elaboration: Jonathan Rauch's term for institutions that pursue truth more effectively than any one individual. Institutions like science and the judiciary provide rules and norms for guiding biased individuals in the direction of truth.

concepts.name: thinking in bets
concepts.shortDefinition: assigning probabilities instead of certainties
concepts.elaboration: Instead of treating a belief as certainly true, assign a probability that it is true.

concepts.name: scout mindset
concepts.shortDefinition: Galef's term for open-minded exploration
concepts.elaboration: Julia Galef's term for trying to explore a topic with an open mind. The opposite is soldier mindset, which means trying hard to defend your belief, as if counterarguments were threats that must be shoved aside.
